conclusion: An L-shaped skateboard (A) is at rest on a rough horizontal surface.
A light spring with spring constant k is fixed to the right end of the skateboard.
A small block (B) is connected to the left end of the spring, and the spring is initially at its natural length.
Another small block (C) slides onto the skateboard from the left with an initial velocity v0.
After traveling a distance s0, block C collides perfectly inelastically with block B, meaning they stick together and move as one.
After this collision, the combined B and C start moving to the right, and eventually, the skateboard (A) also starts moving.
Masses of A, B, and C are all m.
Coefficient of kinetic friction μ between all sliding surfaces.
Maximum static friction is approximately equal to sliding friction.
The spring stays within its elastic limit.
The main focus is on the collision between C and B.
To find the energy loss during this collision, determine the kinetic energy before and after the collision and subtract the two.

premise: Block C starts with velocity v0 and travels a distance s0 on the skateboard before colliding with B. During this time, it experiences frictional force due to the rough surface of the skateboard.
conclusion: The friction force f is: f = μN = μmg

premise: The friction force opposes the motion of block C, so it decelerates as it moves on the skateboard.
conclusion: The work done by the friction force over the distance s0 will cause a loss in kinetic energy of block C.

premise: The work done by friction: W = -f s0 = -μ m g s0
conclusion: The change in kinetic energy is equal to the work done: ΔKE = W = -μ m g s0

premise: So, the kinetic energy just before collision is: KE_before = KE_0 + ΔKE = 1/2 m v0^2 - μ m g s0
conclusion: KE_before = 1/2 m v0^2 - μ m g s0
